titleStmt.title: George Alexander Mirianon vs. John Boyle and R. de Label-Mahy. Criminal

bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Western District Court of Washington, Northern Division.

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of George Alexander Mirianon for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. PETITION OF GEORGE ALEXANDER MIRIANON. 2663
Comes now George Alexander, Mirianon, a resident of France and respectfully makes this application for a Writ of habeas corpus, and alleges as follows:

I. That George Alexander Mirianon is imprisoned and restrained of his liberty by John Boyle and R. de Lobel Mahy, Vice Counsul of France, at the Port of Seattle, State ofWashington, and by the United States Marshal or one of his deputies under and by virtue of either or both of them, under the illegal and unlawful charge as your petitioner is informed and believes and so states the fact to be, that he has been guilty of insubordination to his superior officer while on the French Bark, Gender Faidherbe, and guilty of conduct prejudicial to the good order of said vessel, and that he should be taken and placed on the French Bark, Anna de Bretagne, now lying at Ballard, Port of Seattle, and deported and carried on said vessel to the Republic of France.
II. That said imprisonment and confinement and restraint as aforesaid, is illegal, unlawful and wrongful and arises from the following facts:

III. That your petitioner arrived at the Port of Seattle on a voyage from France on teh 25 day of Dec, 1913, and was charged by said R. de Lobel-Mahy of the following charges, to-wit: That he had been guilty of insubordination to a superior officer while on board the French bark, General Faidherbe,
and that he was guilty of conduct prejudicial to the good order of said vessel.

IV. That pursuant to said compalint, your petitioner was brought before the Hon. A. C. Bowman, U. S. Commissioner, and testimony was given by R. de Lobel-Mahy, Vice Counsul of France relative to said charges as hereinabove stated.

V. That upon hearing the testimony of said R. de Lobel-Mahy Vice Counsul of France and A. C. Bowman, U. S. Commissioner made an Order, directing the Marshal of said Western Division of Washington and the Master of the French Bark, Anne de Bretagne, to deport and carry said George Alexander Marianin to France on said vessel.

VI. That your petitioner is informed and believes and so states the facts to be that said Marshal of theWestern District of Washington, Northern Division and said R. de Lobel-Mahy, or any of their agents acting theoughtor through, under or for them and the Master of the French Bark, Anne de Bretagne, are about to deport and return the daid George Alexander Marianon to the Republic of France in violation of the treaty relations between the United States and France and in violation of the constitution of the United States, in that said Petitioner is being deprived of his liberty without due process of law

This petitioner further states that the said R. de Lobel- Mahy was not present on said Bark, General Faidderbe a nd that he has no knowledge of any of the acts of your petitioner while on said boat, and that siad U. S. Commissioner did not have a rigt to make any Order on the testimony of said R. de Lobel-Mahy, and furthermore, your petitioner states that the Order of said U. S. Commissioner to said Marshal of the Western District of Washington and to the Master of the French Bark, Anne de Bretagne, which your petitioner makes a part of this petition, does not state any specific
date on which said Petitioner had been gulty of said acts as charged. By reason thereof, said return and deportation is illegal and invalid, and wrongfully issued.

VII. THE Petitioner further states that the said Bark wherein the said R. de Label-Mahy and said Marshal of the W. District of Washington or any of their agents acting through of under them, intend to place this petitioner is the Anne de Bretagne, and that said Bark is a sailing vessel and will take a period of from 3 to 9 months to return to France and your petitioner states that under the facts as presented to this Court by said R. de Label-Mahy, said Marshal of the Western Division of Washington, or any person or persons acting by, under or through them, have no right to return said petitioner to France as aforesaid.

VIII. Petioner further states that his return would be unlawful, illegal and contrary to the treaty relations between the United States and France and inviolation of the constitution of the United States, in that it would deprive your petitioner of his liberty without due process of law.

WHEREFORE YOUR PETITIONER PRAYS THAT a Writ of Habeas Corpus be granted through to the said John Boyle, U. S. Marshal for the Western District of Washington and to his deputies or any of them and to said R. de Label-Mahy, Vice Counsul of France, and to such person acting by, through or under them, commanding them and each of them to have the body of said George Alexander Mirianon before your Honor at a time and place therein to be specified, to do and receive what shall thenand there be considered by your Honor concerning him, together with the time and cause of his detention and said writ, and that he may be restored to liberty and that said Vice Counsul be directed to return this petitioner to France by direct route and not by the route as planned out and set forth in this petition.
div1.ab: John J. Sullivan - Atty for Petitioner
